description: From relax +‎ -ed, originally after Latin relaxātus.

adjectives.description: relaxed (comparative more relaxed, superlative most relaxed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, physiology) Made slack or feeble; weak, soft. [from 15th c.]
examples: It was a very wet morning. I woke relaxed and melancholy as in the country, and walked about an hour under cover, in the middle of the town  […] .

entries.meaning: Made more lenient; less strict; lax. [from 17th c.]
examples: The relaxed rules were greatly tightened after the lawsuit.

entries.meaning: Free from tension or anxiety; at ease; leisurely. [from 18th c.]
examples: He's a relaxed kind of guy, he never lets himself get upset.

entries.meaning: (chiefly physics) Without physical tension; in a state of equilibrium. [from 19th c.]
(physiology) Of a muscle: soft, not tensed. [from 19th c.]
simple past tense and past participle of relax
